data.name: About_CDCInfo
data.value:
This application uses several data sources from the CDC. They include:
Top Stories: http://t.cdc.gov/feed.aspx?tpc=26816&fromdate=1/1/2011 Podcasts: http://www2c.cdc.gov/podcasts/searchandcreaterss.asp?topic=flu Weekly Flu Activity: http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/flureport.xml Flu Hospitalizations & Deaths: http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2010-2011/data/AHDRA19.htm

data.name: About_YahooSearchInfo
data.value: Vaccine Shot Locations are provided by Yahoo Local Search.

data.name: FluFacts_FluImpact_AdultSigns
data.value: •Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. •Pain or pressure in the chest or abdomen. •Sudden dizziness. •Confusion. •Severe or persistent vomiting.

data.name: FluFacts_FluImpact_ChildrenSigns
data.value: •Fast breathing or trouble breathing. •Bluish skin color. •Not drinking enough fluids. •Not waking up or not interacting. •Being so irritable that the child does not want to be held. •Flu-like symptoms improve but then return with a fever and a worse cough. •Fever with a rash.

data.name: FluFacts_FluImpact_MainParagraph
data.value: Each flu season, different flu viruses spread and affect people differently based on their body's ability to fight infection.

data.name: FluFacts_KnowTheFlu_Paragraph1
data.value: The flu, more scientifically known as influenza, is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by influenza viruses. The influenza virus usually enters the body through mucus membranes in the mouth, nose or eyes.

data.name: FluFacts_KnowTheFlu_Paragraph2
data.value: There are three types of flu viruses. Type A viruses are found in many kinds of animals, including ducks, chickens, pigs and also humans. The type B virus widely circulates in humans. Type C has been found in humans, pigs, and dogs and causes mild respiratory infections, but does not spark epidemics.

data.name: FluFacts_PreventTheFlu_MainParagraph
data.value: Don't have the flu and don't want to get it? There are some simple health habits you can work into your life to minimize the chances of getting the flu.

data.name: FluFacts_PreventTheFlu_PreventList
data.value: •Wash your hands regularly •Cover your mouth when coughing and sneezing •Take the yearly flu vaccine •Ask your doctor about antivirals

data.name: FluFacts_TreatTheFlu_MainParagraph1
data.value: There are four main options that might be used as flu treatments — vaccines (the flu shot), good hygiene, antibiotics, and over-the-counter medicines. However, only one option – prescription antivirals – can make your illness milder or make you feel better faster.

data.name: FluFacts_TreatTheFlu_MainParagraph2
data.value: The chart below gives you an at-a-glance comparison of each option.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_Aches
data.value: While it is normal to feel body aches from physical overexertion, body aches that are sudden and unexplained can be a sign of the flu.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_Chills
data.value: Chills and shivering are normal as your body reacts to a cold environment. Luckily, you have those warm bunny slippers for cold winter mornings. Chills unrelated to environment can be a sign of the flu.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_Coughing
data.value: Know your cough. A productive cough (coughing up mucus) is common with a cold, while a non-productive or dry cough (with no mucus) is associated with the flu.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_Fever
data.value: A fever occurs when your body temperature increases in response to illness or injury. Your temperature is considered elevated when it is higher than 100°F.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_Sneezing
data.value: A symptom of a cold and the flu, sneezing spreads viruses through droplets in the air. Try to sneeze into a tissue and then wash your hands to reduce the spread of cold and flu.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_SoreThroat
data.value:
Swelling in the throat, sometimes caused by a cold, can lead to a sore throat.
Discover a prescription flu medicine that can help prevent the flu or shorten its duration.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_SuddenSymptoms
data.value: The flu hits hard and comes on quickly, usually in 3 to 6 hours. Sudden symptoms such as high fever (100°F +), aches and pains are typical.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_TirednessFatigue
data.value: It's normal to feel tired at the end of a long day or when you don't get adequate sleep, but unexplained tiredness can be a sign of the flu.

data.name: FluSymptoms_FinalInfo_UnderstandSymptoms
data.value:
Of course, only your doctor or healthcare professional can make an accurate flu diagnosis, but understanding flu symptoms can help protect you and your family.
Answer the following questions, and take it with you to your doctor. Remember, you have 12 to 48 hours to prevent and treat the flu with prescription antivirals, so act quickly.

data.name: FluSymptoms_Question_Sneezing
data.value: Is sneezing activity more than usual?

data.name: FluSymptoms_Question_SoreThroat
data.value: Does patient have a sore throat?

data.name: FluSymptoms_Question_UnderstandSymptoms
data.value: Before we get started, who is this for?

data.name: FluToolsDisclaimer
data.value: DISCLAIMER: This is not a substitute for a professional, on-site medical diagnosis. However, you can use the saved symptoms results for discussion with your doctor or other healthcare professional during your visit, to aid in a professional diagnosis.

data.name: Settings_ConfirmPasscodeMismatchMessage
data.value: Please make sure your passcodes match.

data.name: Settings_LocationMessage
data.value: Allow the app to use your current location to find places. To turn off location for all apps on your phone, go to the Settings app of your Windows Phone.

data.name: Settings_PasscodeHeading
data.value: Protect your data and maintain your privacy.

data.name: Settings_PasscodeNotStoredWarning
data.value: NOTE: Your password is never stored on your device for security purposes. Please choose with care. If you are unable to remember your passcode with the aid of your hint, you will be denied access, and may need to reset your application.

data.name: Settings_PasscodeWarning
data.value: NOTE: Please choose your passcode with care. If you are unable to remember your passcode with the aid of your hint, you will be unable to access your diary, and may need to reset your application.
